todaysEvents.title: Cryptocurrency Sector Losses Exceed $3.35 Billion
todaysEvents.description: A report from CertiK indicates that total losses from hacks, exploits, and scams in the cryptocurrency sector exceeded $3.35 billion this year.

todaysEvents.title: Polymarket User Account Breach via Third-Party Authentication
todaysEvents.description: Polymarket users reported account breaches linked to a third-party authentication vulnerability.

todaysEvents.title: SantaStealer Malware Targets Crypto and Browser Data
todaysEvents.description: A new malware identified as SantaStealer is reportedly targeting and stealing data from web browsers and cryptocurrency wallets.

todaysEvents.title: Gnosis Hard Fork to Recover $116M from Balancer Exploit
todaysEvents.description: Gnosis executed a hard fork to recover funds following a November exploit of Balancer that resulted in $116M in stolen digital assets.

todaysEvents.title: University of Phoenix Data Breach Impacts 3.5 Million
todaysEvents.description: The University of Phoenix confirmed a data breach affecting 3.5 million individuals, stemming from a zero-day vulnerability exploit in Oracle EBS enterprise software attributed to threat groups Cl0p or FIN11.

todaysEvents.title: OMNIBUS JAPAN INC. Breach Claimed by Lynx Group
todaysEvents.description: The Lynx hacking group claimed to have breached OMNIBUS JAPAN INC., a Japanese news and multimedia company. The incident is currently pending verification.

past7Days.briefing: The week ending December 25, 2025, witnessed a pronounced escalation in cyber risk across multiple sectors, highlighted by high-profile data breaches, aggressive exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and record-setting financial losses, particularly in the cryptocurrency domain. Major institutions—including the University of Phoenix, the French Ministry of the Interior, and multiple DeFi platforms—suffered breaches impacting millions, while attackers rapidly weaponized vulnerabilities in widely used products like Fortinet, React, and n8n. The emergence of advanced malware (Stealka, RatOn, SantaStealer) and large-scale phishing and scam campaigns further amplified the threat landscape, with the crypto sector alone reporting over $3.35 billion in annual losses. This convergence of technical exploits, social engineering, and data-theft tactics signals a period of heightened cyber activity requiring urgent, coordinated defensive measures.
past7Days.trends: Key trends observed this week include: 1) Persistent exploitation of newly disclosed vulnerabilities (React2Shell, Fortinet FortiGate, n8n) with rapid deployment of ransomware and credential theft; 2) Massive breaches and leaks targeting educational, governmental, and financial organizations, with attackers leveraging both technical and social attack vectors; 3) A surge in malware and infostealer campaigns targeting crypto users and gamers via trusted platforms like GitHub and SourceForge; 4) Sophisticated scams, especially address poisoning and phishing, causing unprecedented financial losses in crypto; 5) Ongoing targeting of legacy vulnerabilities and supply chain weaknesses, as seen in the Polymarket and Nissan incidents. There is a notable concentration of attacks around crypto, finance, and education, alongside coordinated campaigns against government and manufacturing entities.
past7Days.predictions: For the upcoming days, continued high risk is expected—especially in the cryptocurrency, finance, and education sectors. Advanced persistent groups are likely to intensify exploitation of recently disclosed vulnerabilities and may leverage holiday periods for disruptive attacks. Expect further ransomware incidents, large-scale phishing, and infostealer campaigns (high confidence, 80%). Zero-day exploitation and supply chain attacks will remain prevalent, with attackers targeting platforms with wide user bases (React, Fortinet, cloud services). Crypto scams (address poisoning, wallet malware) will persist, potentially escalating as threat actors adapt tactics. Institutions should prioritize patching, multi-factor authentication, and user education, with particular attention to monitoring for both technical and social engineering threats.
